title: U.S. and European natural gas price 1980 to 2030
summary: You are viewing a chart of multi-line type with 2 lines denoting Europe, and U.S.. The y axis indicates the Price in U.S. dollars per million Btu and the x axis indicates Year.
Overall Europe, and U.S. are gradually increasing,  throughout the Year
The lines ordered according to average values of Price in U.S. dollars per million Btu in descending order is: 1. Europe, and lastly, 2. U.S..
Throughout the period, Europe generally had the highest Price in U.S. dollars per million Btu relative to others with an average of 6.44, and it reached its maximum at 2013 with a value of 11.1.
U.S. mostly had the least Price in U.S. dollars per million Btu with a mean value of 3.09, which peaked at 2000 with a value of 4.8.
yAxis: Price in U.S. dollars per million Btu

max_summary: The given chart is of multi-line type with 2 lines namely Europe, and U.S.. The y axis represents Price in U.S. dollars per million Btu and the x axis represents Year.
Overall Europe, and U.S. are gradually increasing,  throughout the Year
The ranking of the lines from topmost to botommmost is as follows: 1. Europe, and lastly, 2. U.S..
Throughout the period, Europe generally had the highest Price in U.S. dollars per million Btu relative to others with an average of 6.44, and it reached its maximum at 2013 with a value of 11.1.
U.S. mostly had the least Price in U.S. dollars per million Btu with a mean value of 3.09, which peaked at 2000 with a value of 4.8.
U.S. reported the lowest Price in U.S. dollars per million Btu about 1.8 in Year 1990
The greatest difference of Price in U.S. dollars per million Btu between Europe and U.S. occurs at Year 2013 and the smallest difference occurs at 2000.
